elements.name: panel2
elements.title: In Switzerland, voters were able to influence the issue of the nuclear phase-out twice - once directly and once indirectly. In Germany, the people only had an indirect say. Now read the first part of the instrument "Direct, indirect and semi-direct democracy" and then complete the following sentences:

elements.name: Frage 1
elements.title: In Germany, the people were able to have an indirect say on the nuclear phase-out by ...
elements.correctAnswer: ... elected the parliament that decided on the exit.

elements.name: Frage 2
elements.title: In Switzerland, the people were able to have an indirect say on the nuclear phase-out by ...
elements.correctAnswer: ... elected the parliament that prepared the exit.

elements.name: Frage 3
elements.title: In Switzerland, the people were also able to have a direct say on the nuclear phase-out by ...
elements.correctAnswer: ... voted on the energy strategy (or the phase-out or the new law).

elements.name: Frage 4
elements.title: Switzerland is a semi-direct democracy because the electorate can ... and ... influence ....
elements.correctAnswer: Switzerland is a semi-direct democracy because the electorate can influence issues directly and indirectly.

elements.name: Frage 5
elements.title: Assign the co-determination rights according to the diagram. Tip: One term belongs to the intersection of the two forms of democracy.

elements.name: Frage 6
elements.title: Using the diagram and the two terms "direct" and "indirect right of co-determination", explain why Swiss citizens have a dual role in politics:
elements.correctAnswer: Swiss citizens may elect representatives (indirect right of co-determination) and vote on a regular basis (direct right of co-determination). They can also bring about referendums themselves by supporting an optional referendum or a popular initiative (direct right of co-determination).
